summary: Block Access to North Korea Act of 2016 or BANK Act of 2016 This bill requires the President to impose sanctions pursuant to the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, with specified waiver authority, against a person that continues to knowingly and directly provide specialized financial messaging services to, or to knowingly enable or facilitate access to such messaging services for:   the Central Bank of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (North Korea),  a financial institution that facilitates any transaction or provides significant financial services for nuclear development or proliferation on North Korea's behalf, or  a person identified on the list of specially designated nationals and blocked persons maintained by the Department of the Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control for assisting North Korea's nuclear development or proliferation efforts.
predicted_summary: Block Access to North Korea Act of 2016 - This bill directs the U.S. Congress to investigate North Korea's continued ballistic missile and nuclear weapons development and whether the government intends to reduce or eliminate its nuclear weapons program.North Korea's provocations continue to endanger its citizens, those of U.S. allies, and those of Japan, which are directly threatened by North Korea.Authorizes the President to impose sanctions with respect to the provision of specialized financial messaging services to the central bank of the democratic people's republic of Korea and certain other financial institutions and sanctioned persons. Directs the President, on or after the date of the enactment of this Act, to impose penalties for: (1) knowingly and directly providing services to, or knowingly enabling or facilitating access to such messaging services for, North Korea; or (2) a financial institution that facilitates any transaction or transactions or provides significant financial services for North Korea.Directs the President to waive such sanctions with respect to a person if: (1) the person is subject to a sanctions regime under its governing foreign law that requires it to eliminate the knowing provision of such messaging services and the knowing enabling and facilitation of direct or indirect access to such services for, the central bank of the democratic people's republic of Korea, any financial institution described in this Act, and any person described in it; (2) such person has, pursuant to that sanctions regime, terminated such services' knowing provision, and the facilitating and facilitating of such access to, the Central Bank of the DPRK, and such institution's messaging services; and (3) the President determines that such a waiver is in the national interest of the United States.Directs financial institutions to serve as an intermediary financial institution with access to messaging services.

summary: Social Security Protection Act of 2011 - Makes it out of order in the Senate or the House of Representatives to consider any legislation that: (1) increases the retirement age or the early retirement age for individuals receiving benefits under title II (Old Age, Survivors, and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act on or after the enactment of this Act; (2) reduces cost-of-living increases for them; (3) reduces benefit payment amounts for them; or (4) creates private retirement accounts for any of the OSADI benefits they receive.
predicted_summary: Social Security Protection Act of 2011 - Provides for the protection of senior citizens, individuals with disabilities, and their children from poverty.Social Security Trust Fund (SSAF) Balance-sheet Adjustment Act - Directs the Social Security Administration to maintain a $2 billion surplus through 2023, with enough funding remaining after 2037 to pay about 78 percent of benefits.Social Security and the Disability Insurance Program for American Retirees:  (1) provide the majority of income for two-thirds of the elderly population in the United States, with approximately one-third of retirees receiving nearly all of their income from Social Security.Amends the Social Security Act to prohibit the Senate or the House of Representatives from considering, for purposes of the old-age, survivors, and disability insurance benefits program established under title ii of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERSISA), any legislation that increases the retirement age for current and future retirees.Amends the Social Security Act to: (1) reduce benefit payment amounts for individuals receiving benefits under title ii of this Act on or after the date of enactment; or (2) create private retirement accounts for eligible individuals.Sets forth provisions of this Act requiring the Speaker of the House of Representatives to entertain a motion to suspend the application of this section.

summary: Gold King Mine Spill Accountability Act of 2016 This bill requires the Department of Justice (DOJ) to appoint a special investigator to investigate: (1) who was at fault for the discharge of contaminated water from the Gold King Mine north of Silverton, Colorado, into Cement Creek; (2) which individuals were responsible for the decisions that led to the spill; and (3) what downstream environmental effects were caused by the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) actions, or inactions, after the spill.  The bill: (1) entitles individuals to receive compensation for a claim filed, or civil action brought, under the Federal Tort Claims Act relating to an injury resulting from the spill, and (2) establishes within the EPA the Office of Gold King Mine Spill Claims for processing claims of allowable damages resulting from the spill. The EPA may provide compensation for a claim in an amount greater than $25,000 without the prior approval of DOJ. The EPA must fund the implementation of the long-term monitoring program developed by the Long-Term Impact Review Team of New Mexico, for the water quality of the Animas and San Juan Rivers. The EPA may not finalize or work on any rules (including those not related to the spill) until all claims have been paid, except rules that are necessary to address an imminent threat to public health or safety, or other emergency.
predicted_summary: Gold King Mine Liability Accountability Act of 2016 - Directs the Attorney General to appoint a special investigator to investigate the environmental protection agency role in the gold king mine spill.Special Investigators may issue subpoenas requiring the attendance and testimony of witnesses and the production of any evidence relating to any matter that the Special investigator is investigating.Requires the Special Investigator to apply to a U.S. district court for an order requiring the person to appear before the Special investigator to give testimony, produce evidence, or both, relating to the matter under investigation.Requires the Comptroller General to report to Congress on the results of an audit of the investigation.Directs the President pro tempore of the Senate to refer to the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources and Environment and Public Works reports to the Senate regarding compensation for a spill of the gold king mine.Provides that the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) shall: (1) receive, process, and pay claims in accordance with this Act; and (2) distribute such compensation to the affected individuals.Prohibits a claim for loss of property for: (1) any cost resulting from lost tribal subsistence from hunting, fishing, firewood gathering, timbering, grazing, or agricultural activities or from lost use for traditional or ceremonial uses, conducted on land or using water damaged by the gold mine spill; (2) any costs associated with the cost of reforestation or revegetation on tribal or non-federal land, to the extent that the cost is not covered by any other federal program; and (3) any other costs borne by an injured person to pay for water supplies or equipment to treat water.Provides that: (1) a claim for business loss may include damages resulting from the gold king mine spill for: (2) damage to tangible assets or inventory; (3) business interruption losses; (4) employee wages for work not performed; and (5) any other loss that the Administrator determines to be appropriate for inclusion as a business loss.Gold King Mine Injury Act - Amends Federal law to: (1) require plaintiffs to bring a negligence or wrongful act or omission claim against a Federal officer, employee, contractor, or subcontractor under circumstances in which the federal officer, if a private person, would be liable to the claimant in accordance with the law of the jurisdiction.Requires the Administrator to fund the implementation of the long-term monitoring program developed by the Long-Term Impact Review Team of the State of New Mexico for the water quality of the Animas and San Juan Rivers.3,000,000 gallons of contaminated water from the Gold King Mine north of silverton, Colorado, into cement creek that occurred while contractors of the Environmental Protection Agency were conducting an investigation of the gold king mine.

summary:
Rural Broadband Access Enhancement Act - Amends the Rural Electrification Act of 1936 to redefine "eligible rural community."

Permits a loan or loan guarantee applicant in an area where 40% of the residents are without broadband access to qualify with a 10% loan equity position.

Provides for: (1) paperwork reduction; and (2) program outreach to underserved areas.

Prohibits loan or loan guarantees for new broadband service in communities with three or more service providers.

Provides that for each fiscal year: (1) not more than 10% of program funds shall be available to providers with more than 10% of national subscriber lines; and (2) 40% of program funds shall be available to providers with between 2%-10% of national subscriber lines.

Revises the amortization period from the life of the asset to 35 years.

Requires an annual broadband program report to Congress.
predicted_summary: Rural Broadband Access Enhancement Act - Amends the Rural Interoperability and Access Act of 1936 to establish an eligible rural community, which is: (1) not included within the urbanized area contiguous and adjacent to such a city, town, borough, or village; and (2) not in the urbanizationally adjacent area. Directs the Secretary of the Interior to develop a plan to construct a rural broadband access enhancement program for eligible rural communities.Requires the Secretary to approve an application submitted to serve: (1) an area in which at least 40 percent of the population does not have access to broadband service; or (2) any other area where the applicant not pledged or hypothecated for any other purpose equals at least 15 percent of principal amount of the loan involved.Amends the Rural Electrification Act of 1936 to prohibit the secreary from approving an application for a loan or loan guarantee for new broadband service in an eligible rural community with three or more service providers.Amends the Rural Electrification Act of 1936 to: (1) extend the useful life of the assets constructed, improved, or acquired with the proceeds of the loan or extension of credit; and (2) require such entities to provide loans or loan guarantees to entities with less than 2 percent and not more than 10% of the telephone subscriber lines installed in the United States.Requires the Secretary to submit to the Committee on Agriculture and to the Committees on Nutrition, Nutrition, and Forestry of the Senate a report on the status of the program.

summary:
Wounded Warrior Transition Assistance Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of each military department to provide each reserve member of that department who is being evaluated for separation or retirement for disability, or for placement on the temporary disability retired list or inactive status list, the option to remain on active duty during such evaluation in order to continue to receive military pay and allowances, until the member is: (1) cleared to return to duty; or (2) separated, retired, or placed on the temporary disability retired or inactive status list.

Requires each Secretary to retain on active duty (for pay and allowances purposes) a reserve member who incurs an injury or illness while on active duty, is being discharged or separated from the Armed Forces, or is being released from active duty, and is not being evaluated in connection with such discharge, separation, or release, until the member is: (1) retired or placed on the temporary disability retired or inactive status list; or (2) determined ineligible for such care or benefits based solely upon the injury or illness.

Requires military human resources commands to return to active duty during their evaluation period reserve members who request such option.

Encourages the use of local residences by reserve members during such transition periods.

Authorizes the use of Defense Health Program funds for reserve members who become ill or injured while on active duty and separate as a result of such illness or injury.

Provides for the assignment of Judge Advocate General personnel to assist members of the Armed Forces (members) in connection with the medical discharge process and disability evaluations.

Expresses support for access of veterans service organizations to military facilities to provide counseling and services to members.
predicted_summary: Wounded Warrior Transition Assistance Act of 2009 - Amends the Uniformed Services and Public Health Service Act of 1974 to authorize the Secretary of Defense to give a member of a reserve component under his or her jurisdiction for separation or retirement for disability or for placement on the temporary disability retired list or inactive status list an option to remain on active duty.Requires the Secretary of Defense to retain on active duty a member of a reserve component who incurs an injury or illness, is being discharged or separated from the Armed Forces, or is released from active duty in order to continue to receive pay and allowances.Requires the Human Resources Command to return a member of an Armed Forces reserve component to active duty for specified purposes.Requires the Army, the Marine Corps, and the Coast Guard to: (1) report to the appropriate authorities on the cause and prevention of an illness or injury; and (2) make a determination of eligibility for placement on the temporary disability retired list. Prohibits the Army from discharging human resources functions with respect to members of the armed forces.Requires the Secretary of Defense to pay any reasonable expenses of transportation, lodging, and meals incurred by a member residing at the member's permanent place of residence if residing at that location is medically feasible, as determined by a licensed health care provider.Protects the Defense Health Program funds for support programs for any member of a Reserve Component who becomes ill or injured while on active duty and separates from active duty as a result of the illness or injury. Directs the Secretary of Defense to coordinate with the reserve components, including the National Guard, in determining the budget requirements for the support programs.Requires the Secretary of each Military Department to ensure that each member of the Armed Forces under the DOD's jurisdiction is receiving appropriate assistance on all legal matters relating to medical discharge from the armed forces.Directs the Secretary to ensure that each member of the Armed Forces under such Secretary who is undergoing disability evaluation receives appropriate assistance on all legal matters relating to such evaluation.Directs the Secretary of Defense and the VA to jointly prescribe in regulations for representation of members of the Armed Forces undergoing disability evaluation.Requires the Secretary of Defense to disseminate information regarding the existence and availability of the wounded warrior resource center.Directs the Department of Defense to establish a special fund for the recovery of DOD misappropriated funds.
